K-Culture will showcase performances by the band P1Harmony, featuring Markham’s own Korean-Canadian singer Yoon Keeho. - Photo courtesy of ROM Get things shaking with a K-pop band and a host of Korean contemporary culture. The Royal Ontario Museum (ROM) is launching the new season of ROM After Dark with K-Culture taking the lead. K-Culture will showcase performances by the band P1Harmony, featuring Markham’s own Korean-Canadian singer Yoon Keeho. Keeho (Stephen) was born in Toronto in 2001, grew up in Markham and went to Unionville High School. He was trained for almost three years prior to his debut and was introduced as the first member of P1Harmony. Keeho’s soulful voice is quite distinct throughout P1Harmony’s music and covers. He also has writing credits on several songs throughout P1Harmony’s discography, including “That’s It,” “Reset” and “If You Call Me.” Since debuting in 2020 with the release of “Siren,” P1Harmony have come out with five new albums, including the recent “Harmony: Zero In.” The title song, “Doom Du Doom,” has been viewed on YouTube over ten million times as their fan base grows. ROM After Dark: K-Culture will be launched on Friday, Sept. 16, from 7:30 p.m. to 11:30 p.m. While driven by K-pop’s signature musical hooks, ROM After Dark: K-Culture will showcase a variety of Korean arts and culture in the forms of animation, calligraphy, fashion, music and dance. Visitors can join and display moves with Dance like a K-pop Star with Toronto’s RPM Dance Crew, take a shot at Korean Karaoke stardom or get dancing with DJ Yuka K and DJ Korea Town Acid. Sample Korean animation shorts such as “Manimals” by Oh Jihyeon, “Apartment” by Lee Jui and “Shining Night” by Yang Hyeonseo. For a more relaxed vibe, you can enjoy Korean tea tasting with certified tea sommelier Soo Park of Soocha Tea, groove to Korean contemporary jazz or enjoy the instrumental meditation sounds from musicians from the Korean Traditional Music Association of Canada. Get the unique experience of donning traditional attire in the Hanbok selfie station; hanbok is a type of traditional dress that remains an important part of Korean culture and is worn on special occasions. Tickets are $30 and can be purchased online. ROM members get 10 per cent off. ROM After Dark is the museum's monthly evening cultural social event for adults. The popular series features curated performances, music, gallery access and a night out on the town with an eclectic mix of bar refreshments and food from themed pop-up stations. ROM After Dark returns for six more Friday evenings with new themes and new things to do and enjoy.
